metadata.case_name: Assessee Bank v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee is a Bank carrying on banking business.
For the assessment year 1945-46, assessable income computed by Income Tax Officer at Rs. 14,95,826 by splitting income into interest on securities Rs. 23,62,815 and business loss Rs. 8,86,972.
In the previous year, loss of Rs. 3,21,929 computed by setting off business loss against interest on securities.

Assessee claimed entitlement to set off carried over loss of previous year against profits of 1945-46 under s.24(2) of the Act, contending dealing in securities is part of banking business as defined by s.277F Indian Companies Act.
Income Tax Officer rejected claim as loss under business head, no set off under s.24(2).
On appeal to Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, contention repeated that assessee is dealer in securities, two heads part of same business; repelled.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held ss.6,8,10 keep income from two sources separate, refused set-off.
Tribunal stated case to Calcutta High Court on questions including whether entitled to set off business loss Rs.3,21,929 against interest on securities; whether deductions under s.8 provisos.
High Court answered all questions in negative; Chief Justice held heads under s.6 mutually exclusive, interest on securities not business income.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate from High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether interest on securities held by a bank as trading assets falls under s.8 or s.10 of the Indian Income-tax Act.
Whether assessee entitled to set off carried over business loss of previous year against income from interest on securities under s.24(2).
Whether assessee entitled under s.8 to deduct administrative expenses or interest on borrowed money for tax-free securities from interest on securities.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss.8 and 10 to be read so interest on securities as trading assets excluded from s.8, falls under business head s.10; alternatively s.10 more appropriate.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss.8,10 Indian Income-tax Act; Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ahmuty & Co. Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: If ss.8 and 10 equally applicable, assessee has option to be taxed under head imposing lighter burden.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Bros.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if heads mutually exclusive, entitled to set-off under s.24(2) as interest on securities and business profits from different operations of same banking business.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.24(2) Indian Income-tax Act; s.277F Indian Companies Act; Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

respondent_arguments.text: Heads under s.6 mutually exclusive; interest on securities falls specifically under s.8 regardless of trading or capital asset.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss.6,8,10 Indian Income-tax Act; Probhat Chandra Barua v. King Emperor; form of return under s.22(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Set-off under s.24(2) only against profits of same business under s.10, not against s.8 interest on securities.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Act: s.6 enumerates mutually exclusive heads; ss.7-12 provide computation modes; income from whatever source falls under specific head.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interest on securities taxable under s.8 even if held as trading assets by bank.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents confirm heads exclusive: e.g., Salisbury House Estate v. Fry; Rowlatt J. in Butler v. Mortgage Company of Egypt: cannot escape specific head by embedding in business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specific head prevails over business head.

court_reasoning.text: 1955 amendment to s.8 proviso allowing banks deduction for realising interest supports s.8 applicability to banks.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislative intent confirms s.8 for all interest on securities.

court_reasoning.text: No option for assessee or Revenue to choose head; no finding that securities part of same business for s.24(2) set-off.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Issue not decided due to resolution on heads exclusivity.

holdings.text: Heads of income under s.6 mutually exclusive; interest on securities falls under specific head s.8, not s.10 even for bank trading assets.
No set-off of business loss against interest on securities under s.24(2) as different heads.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ahmuty & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dividend income of share dealer under s.10, not s.12.

precedents_cited.case_name: Probhat Chandra Barua v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: s.6 as charging section, heads exclusive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Salisbury House Estate Ltd. v. Fry
precedents_cited.relevance: Schedules mutually exclusive; income under specific schedule cannot be under another.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Chunilal Mehta
precedents_cited.relevance: s.6 classifies sources distinctly; business distinct from investment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Butler v. Mortgage Company of Egypt Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest on securities taxed under specific provision even if part of business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thompson v. Trust and Loan Company of Canada
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot treat specific taxed income differently for business computation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commercial Properties Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Income from property under s.9, not business s.10.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.C. Kothari v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: s.8 separate head; no change to another head.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Bros.
precedents_cited.relevance: Option if multiple heads, but not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Banking involves dealing in securities as normal business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: New points arguable if question wide enough.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Heads of income mutually exclusive; interest on securities under s.8; no set-off of business loss against s.8 income under s.24(2); computation modes.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines banking business including investment in securities.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court and Tribunal; interest on securities assessed under s.8 separately from business; no set-off of prior business loss against it under s.24(2); questions on s.8 deductions also negative.

key_quotes.text: "The various heads of income, profits and gains have been so classified that the items falling under those heads become chargeable under ss.7 to 12 according as they are income of which the source is salaries, interest on securities, property, business..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains mutual exclusivity of heads under s.6.

key_quotes.text: "Income derived by a trading company from investments of its funds... in government securities must be taxed under Sch. C, and cannot... be brought into account." (Lord Atkin in Salisbury House)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Supports specific head over business head.

key_quotes.text: "A banker could never ask to be repaid the tax which had been deducted from the Government securities which he held, because he held them as a banker..." (Rowlatt J.)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bankers cannot treat securities interest as business income.
